body:
I implemented some more fine-grained handling of C++ exceptions: `std::bad_alloc` becomes a `MemoryError` on the Python side, arithmetic errors become (subclasses of) `ArithmeticError`, and exceptions from by IOstreams become `IOError`.

`std::domain_error` still becomes a `ValueError`, since it denotes what the latter's docstring calls an "Inappropriate argument value."

comment_data.body: Why do you use void here?
Because this is a function that doesn't return a value.
Oh sorry, I mean void inside argument list.
Oh... slip of the mind, I guess. I don't have the habit of writing that `void` there. Do you mind if I force-push a new version of this commit?

commit.message: Catch a few arithmetic exceptions from C++ as well
Handle std::ios_base::failure as well as possible
Add tests for fine-grained exception handling

C++ exceptions: test ios_base::failure and underflow_error

Also make bad_alloc test more reliable.
Translate C++ std::bad_cast exception to Python TypeError
document fine-grained C++ exceptions in the user guide

title: Fine-grained handling of C++ exceptions
